data.title: Extensions: Allow disabling specific extensions
data.body:
Allow extensions to be disabled. There are a bunch of them, which I know I won't use. But I might just need them at a certain point. While VSCode is quite clever and loads only while needed, there's still a bunch of stuff that's better left disabled in certain cases. Or while testing, it would very helpul to be able to switch them on and off. 

Also, it would be nice to have the disabled ones to NOT check for updates automatically while disabled. So, the sidebar only notifies on the extensions you care about. Its particularly annoying when it keeps showing up new notifications for extension you really don't care much about.

data.title: JavaScript IntelliSense not working correctly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Issue: JavaScript IntelliSense does not activate until the file has been saved, closed and re-opened.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create HTML file
2. Create Javascript file
3. Type "do" and all that will show is a dowhile suggestion.
4. Save Javascript file
5. Close Javascript file
6. Re-open Javascript file and IntelliSene all of a sudden starts working on that file.

![errorpic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15789820/17080186/83731458-50eb-11e6-9109-d7675168eb2c.png)

![workingafterreopen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15789820/17080195/c0b3b1ce-50eb-11e6-842f-03afc7358853.png)

data.title: Open an Http Url from extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Darwin Kernel Version 15.6.0

Hello folks,
I'm actually working on a VSCode extension which is linting a document and sometimes it might fail due to wrong settings (for example, I cannot provide symbols location if the user does not enable sourcemaps for the parser).

When this happens, I'm showing a `warning` message, which is totally ok. Obviously the space there is limited; therefore I wanted to provide a `More Info` button which, when clicked, it will open a webpage (potentially a Github wiki) with a more detailed explanation of the problem.

To do that, I'm using `sendNotification` from the server sending the interested URL but, unfortunately, I didn't find any way to open an `http` URI from the client application. It looks like `vscode.previewHtml` does not support `http/s` schemas.

What would be the best way to do that?

data.title: How can we reuse editor of another language in any file
data.body:
Basically it like HTML can edit css and javascript in `<style>` and `<script>` tag

I am using couchDB and have a hard time edit its document. couchdb work with javascript in json so I need to write javascript in string

something like this

``` JSON
{
  "_id": "_design/_auth",
  "language": "javascript",
  "updates": {
    "test": "function (doc, req) {\n if(!req.id)\n return [null,JSON.stringify([doc,req])];\n}"
  }
}
```

Something like this. It hard and ugly so I want to make it easy by developing vscode extension

Could you please guide me?

Also I have heard from typescript team that vscode still lack this feature so they can't put salsa editor in HTML file. If it's true then I would like to make feature request

data.title: suggest unexpected completion items including special character.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- Mac OSX
- VS Code 1.3.1
- vscode-go 0.6.39

With displaying completion widget, when inputting a character VSCode cannot 
correctly filter completion items including special characters (`$`, `_`, `/` and so on).

![vscode-js](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1453749/17075967/5cacc914-50e0-11e6-835c-921e4780fd3b.png)

I think that special character is not equal to upper case for matching camel case.
In this case, VSCode should suggest `ArrayBufferConstructor` and `abc`.
(And I cannot understand why `a$b_c` isn't suggested.)

In golang this issue is particularly problematic, since most of package name is separated `/` (e.g. `io/ioutil`, `internal/golang.org/x/net/http2/hpack`).
[Search relevance in 'Add import' · Issue #390 · Microsoft/vscode-go](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/390)

---

When filtering completion items, VSCode seems to consider the keyword including special characters camel case.
[vscode/filters.ts at 35e5c9af12045c89790be81d51a742dd7c2a30c4 · Microsoft/vscode](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/35e5c9af12045c89790be81d51a742dd7c2a30c4/src/vs/base/common/filters.ts#L168)

Is this  bug?

data.title: Show long file and folder names on hover in the file explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Win10 Build 14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Expand a couple folders deep (such as the contents of `bower_components`)
2. Watch your file and folder names get cut off
3. Profit

I'd like to see a tooltip or something that displays the full file or folder name on hover if it's cut off. This also makes multiple files that start with the same value impossible to tell which is which since they're clipped.

A horizontal scrollbar in the explorer might be nice as well, but the tooltip would be enough.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/831974/17075573/98382314-5065-11e6-98bc-25bb605a9517.PNG)

data.title: Add javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterNameForNamedFunctions option
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Pro 64-bit

It'd be nice to have an option like `javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterNameForNamedFunctions` such that setting it to `true` causes Alt+Shift+F to reformat `function foo() { }` to `function foo () { }`.

This could be done with a more generic solution by inferring from linter options as mentioned via #4374. However, some tools might enforce options in a way that inferring could possibly be difficult (says me, a pretty serious JS newbie). For example, when using [`standard`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard) and [`vscode-standardjs`](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=chenxsan.vscode-standardjs), I'm not sure how this rule's presence could be easily detected. (But maybe I just haven't thought about it hard enough.)

data.title: Add file walk telemetry
No immediate notification that side-loaded extension was successfully installed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: 10.11.3

Side-loading an extension through the `File -> Open` interface does not show any notification in the interface that installation was successful. Only the extensions tab shows that the installation was successful.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Select `File - Open`
2. Select a `.vsix` file in the file picker
3. Observe that the interface does not show any notification.

Gif of me installing a side loaded extension, `KiteCode`:
![kitecode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/87996/17070452/df40d774-5010-11e6-8e53-586d7ce6bfa2.gif)

data.title: close icon on terminal/console/etc. pane should be "x"
data.body:
The terminal, debug output, console, etc. panes at the bottom have a small down arrow for the action to close or hide the pane. clicking on this makes the pane slide down and disappear.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1487073/17070050/be6381c0-500e-11e6-85d9-0d7f74099e70.png)

The down arrow to me suggests that the window will be collapsed down rather than closed. Whenever I click on this I expect there to be an action at the bottom of the editor to restore the pane. Instead I have to use the keyboard or menu to bring these back.

As a result, a better icon for this pane would be the close "x".  

Alternatively, there should be a visualization at the bottom of the editor that there is a pane that can be restored.

data.title: Which version of TypeScript is Visual Studio Code "Insiders" using?
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.4.0-insider (commit 01a3f86)
- OS Version:Windows 7 x64

I get inconsistent behaviour between the typescript compiler (installed with `npm install -g typescript@next`) and the TypeScript language services included in Visual Studio Code "Insiders".
To get a quick fix [for this TypeScript issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript), I installed the development version, currently Version 2.1.0-dev.20160722, of typescript via npm.
Now, the issue is gone when I build the application with the typescript task (on save) inside of Visual Studio Code "Insiders".
However, when I edit the source code (just adding a newline at the end or other insignificant changes), the error pops right up again without invoking tsc via the task but using the built-in TypeScript language services of the editor.

The Info output of Visual Studio Code "Insiders" in the menu "Help" -> "Info" does not show the TypeScript version used, either.

What is the TypeScript language service version that Visual Studio Code "Insiders" uses for its internal editor, then?

I have configured the following problem matcher:

data.title: Not all rulers are being displayed when using zoom level less than 0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider (2016-07-22T05:07:03.113Z)
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In settings, setup editor.rulers to [71, 99]
2. Setup window.zoomLevel to -1
3. Setup editor.fontSize to 13
4. Reload Window
5. Open any file
6. Open split editor window (ctrl+)

After above, most of the time the 2nd ruler at the left window does not show up.  This only started manifesting on newer version (no problem with older version)

data.title: Advice / Best Practices request: React / JSX / eslint setup
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: 10.11.5

I really like VSC and it's interesting when you start a Typescript project how everything seems to light up in terms of linter/debugging without any config.

But using ES6, JSX, etc. I'm having a really hard time getting the editor to cooperate. Would love to see a Best Practice guide here for what is a common great setup for a React JSX project (not exactly an 'under-the-radar' tech).  

I tried the popular ESLint extension and out of the box it's popping up annoying "React is defined but never used" because JSX calls `React.createElement` but that's obviously not present in the file. Even if this is an ESLint problem, I'd love to hear the VSC community's solutions for this.

Sorry if Github Issues ain't the right place for this, but [Idea Board](https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/293070-visual-studio-code) only suggests here for  discussions.

data.title: VS Code 1.3 broke telemetry debug output events
data.body:
As of VS Code version 1.3, the C# and C++ extensions are no longer seeing any telemetry events from VS Code. Here is an example telemetry event that our extension sends:

E output: {"category":"telemetry","output":"VS/Diagnostics/Debugger/Launch","data":{"VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.ImplementationName":"Microsoft.MIDebugEngine","VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.EngineVersion":"14.0.30715.1","VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.HostVersion":"1.0.20720.1","VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.AdapterId":"coreclr","VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.Launch.Duration":922,"VS.Diagnostics.Debugger.Launch.IsCoreDump":false},"type":"output"}

The last version that we see any telemetry for is 1.2.1.
Here is our package.json AI Key: https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/blob/master/package.json#L157

data.title: lineHighlight added to Find but not Search; low highlight contrast
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.4.0-insider 01a3f868552dc8011adf4e79bee8cfb09babfe31 - OS Version: macOS El Capitan Steps to Reproduce: 1. "Edit" > "Find" 2. Type in something to find in the current editor 3. When it finds the string in your document a lineHighlight is added. @alexandrudima, since this does not also occur in our Search viewlet, it feels inconsistent to me. Also, this line highlight reduces the contrast of the highlighted found text, making it harder to see what is found. Visual Studio IDE also does not use the lineHighlight for this. After looking issue #2792, I can see the underlying problem that was trying to be solved with helping users find the active highlight, but perhaps it would not be needed if we had a stronger highlight color contrast. At a minimum we should increase that highlight contrast anyway since it would be beneficial with or without the line highlight. **Options:** - **Keep the lineHighlight** (also add it to Search for consistency) and increase contrast on the highlight for found text. - **Remove lineHighlight** and increase contrast on the highlight for found text. - **Darken the lineHighlight color** so it can be stronger in contrast (may be detrimental to the experience of "Go to line", making the found line be less obvious). @stevencl do you have any thoughts on this?

data.title: Shortcut to increase font size using keyboard with numpad
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

While using the `+` and `-` keys on the numpad, `CMD -` will decrease font but `CMD +` will not increase the font size. `CMD +` Does work for the `+` button near the delete key however.

data.title: Colors sepcified in the themes are not rendered correctly.
data.body: - VSCode Version: Latest — 1.3.1 - OS Version: OS X — 10.11.3 Hello, I hope you're doing great today. As I was designing a theme for Code, I noticed what renders is not what I've specified. I know that you may say fonts render with many shading so the final coloring may be changed and that's why I tried every color that I specified and even the background colors rendered incorrectly. I don't know if it's a feature (which if it is, it's really a bad one) or a bug. If this is a bug I really hope that this issue helps you. But if it's part of the architecture; how it applies to colors and how can I choose a color in a way that after your filter it looks the way I want? Thanks a lot Pouya

data.title: Scroll highlight text within integrated terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.0 (e724f269ded347b49fcf1657fc576399354e6703, 2016-07-07T16:52:42.674Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

Problem:
Unable to highlight and copy content that is longer than viewable terminal window.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch integrated terminal
2. Produce text within the terminal that requires you to scroll to see all of it.
3. Scroll to the top with mouse
4. Click to highlight from the top
5. Continue to highlight all the content by scrolling down
6. You will be unable to scroll to capture all of the content

Expected behavior:
Should be able to scroll with highlighted content to the bottom of the terminal window.

data.title: [Bug] Html Snippet Auto-complete with multiple cursors only first line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. The easy way is to install [jhon's papa Angular 2 TypeScript Snippets](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=johnpapa.Angular2) addon.
2. Open html file, add new lines, select them with multicursor and try to use any snippet.
3. It will only fill the first line with the snippet, see example output below.

Input:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9698639/17063214/d5163b00-4ffb-11e6-9ba0-f3db5ad7d226.png)

Output after applying snippet:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9698639/17063026/04440f16-4ffb-11e6-9acf-8ff58172d84f.png)
### Note:

The Angular 2 snippet is an easy way to test, however similar thing happens with normal tags:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9698639/17063196/b95c04bc-4ffb-11e6-9244-a294bcb2a459.png)

Output after applying snippet:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9698639/17063167/933d5e2a-4ffb-11e6-8a50-a39d6626e7b1.png)
